metadata.title: Advanced Week 6 — Monday (Day 1)
keyFeatures: Reduced accessories (3 sets vs 4 in accumulation)

structuredWorkout.title: Lower: Squat Emphasis
structuredWorkout.description: Week 2 of wave loading: 82.5% 1RM for 4x3 @ RPE 8-9 (heavier than Week 5's 80%, but one fewer rep per set). Volume decreases (12 total reps vs 16), intensity increases. Bar speed critical: if third rep grinds (>3sec), reduce weight 5-10lbs next set. Accessories reduced to preserve energy for heavy compounds. Competition > hitting percentages.

sections.title: Warm-Up
sections.overview: Thorough preparation for 82.5% squats — critical at this intensity

exercises.name: Bike or Row

intensity.description: Light sweat, prepare for heavy loading

exercises.notes: Gradually elevate heart rate and body temperature

exercises.name: Hip Circles
exercises.notes: Large circles, open up hip capsule — hips get stiff with heavy squats

exercises.name: Leg Swings
exercises.notes: Forward/back and side-to-side — loosen hip flexors and adductors

exercises.name: Ankle Mobility (Wall Drives)
exercises.notes: Drive knee toward wall while keeping heel down — critical for squat depth

exercises.name: Empty Bar Squats
exercises.notes: Focus on movement quality — depth, bar path, breathing pattern

exercises.name: Goblet Squats
exercises.notes: Light dumbbell — practice upright torso and depth

exercises.name: Paused Squats (Bar Only)
exercises.notes: Practice maintaining tension in the hole — important for heavy lifts

exercises.name: Build-Up Sets (Gradual Load Increase)

intensity.description: Bar → 135 → 185 → 225 → 275 → working weight

exercises.notes: Example for 400lb 1RM (330lb working weight): Bar×10, 135×5, 185×3, 225×2, 275×1, then 330×3. Each set deliberate — build confidence.

exercises.name: Competition Squat (High-Bar or Low-Bar)

intensity.description: 82.5% 1RM — Wave Loading Week 2. Third rep challenging but fast. If it grinds (>3sec), reduce 5-10lbs next set.

exercises.tempo: 2-3 sec descent, 0.5 sec pause at bottom, explosive up
exercises.notes: Setup: Maximum tightness—big breath (fill belly and brace), upper back locked (squeeze bar into traps), confident approach (you own this weight). Walkout: 2-3 steps max, no repositioning (wastes energy). Execution: Descend with control (2-3sec, don't dive), hit depth (parallel or below), pause 0.5sec at bottom (maintain tension, don't relax), DRIVE explosively (push through floor, hips and chest rise together). Focus: Speed off the bottom (if you're slow out of the hole, power is lost). Bar speed check: first rep should move well, second rep slows slightly, third rep is hard but should complete in <3sec. If third rep grinds excessively or stalls, weight is too heavy—reduce 10lbs next set. Rest 3-4min between sets (sit down, sip water, mentally reset). Record: weight, reps completed, RPE per set, bar speed on each rep (fast/moderate/slow/grind), depth confidence, any form breakdown (chest collapse? hips shoot up?). This data is critical for Week 7 (85% 3x3).

sections.title: Secondary Lift
sections.overview: Front squat — lighter secondary squat work

exercises.name: Front Squat OR High-Bar Squat

intensity.description: 60-65% of back squat 1RM — reduced from accumulation (was 3x6)

exercises.notes: Purpose: Maintains squat frequency (2x per week for skill retention), quad emphasis, lighter than Monday's primary squat. Front squat: Bar rests on front delts (elbows high, chest up), teaches upright torso. High-bar squat: If you do low-bar on competition squat, high-bar here provides variation. Focus: Speed and quality, not load. Volume reduced from accumulation phase to preserve energy for main lift.

sections.title: Accessories
sections.overview: Minimal accessories — reduced volume from accumulation

exercises.name: Romanian Deadlift (RDL)

intensity.description: Hamstring/glute strength — reduced from 3x8 in accumulation

exercises.notes: Execution: Hinge at hips, push hips back, feel hamstring stretch (bar to mid-shin), squeeze glutes to return. Don't round lower back. Purpose: Hamstring/glute hypertrophy, posterior chain balance. Volume reduced to preserve recovery capacity for heavy squats.

exercises.name: Leg Press

intensity.description: Quad hypertrophy without spinal load (recovery-friendly)

exercises.notes: Setup: Feet shoulder-width, mid-platform. Execution: Lower with control (full ROM, deep stretch), push through heels, full extension but don't lock knees aggressively. Purpose: Quad volume without CNS demand—allows hypertrophy work without taxing recovery.

sections.title: Cooldown
sections.overview: Static stretching and light foam rolling

exercises.name: Quad Stretch
exercises.notes: Pull heel toward glutes, feel stretch in front of thigh

exercises.name: Hip Flexor Stretch
exercises.notes: Lunge position, drive hips forward, feel stretch in front of rear leg hip

exercises.name: Glute Stretch (Figure-4)
exercises.notes: Lie on back, cross ankle over opposite knee, pull knee toward chest

exercises.name: Foam Rolling (Quads, IT Band)

intensity.description: Focus on sore areas, gentle pressure

exercises.notes: Roll slowly, pause on tender spots for 20-30sec — avoid aggressive pressure when fatigued

structuredWorkout.title: Upper: Bench Emphasis
structuredWorkout.description: Week 2 of wave loading: 82.5% 1RM for 4x3 @ RPE 8-9. Heavier than Week 5 (80%), but one fewer rep. Third rep challenging but controlled—if it stalls mid-press or takes >3sec, reduce 5lbs next set. Perfect setup critical at this intensity. Accessories minimal except face pulls (shoulder health). Track bar speed and path.

sections.title: Warm-Up
sections.overview: Thorough preparation for 82.5% bench — perfect setup is critical

exercises.name: Light Cardio

intensity.description: Walk, bike, or row — conversational pace

exercises.notes: Elevate heart rate, warm muscles and joints

exercises.name: Arm Circles
exercises.notes: Forward and backward — loosen shoulder joints, increase ROM

exercises.name: Band Pull-Aparts
exercises.notes: Activate rear delts and scapular retractors — essential for bench setup and shoulder health

exercises.name: Scapular Push-Ups
exercises.notes: In push-up position, protract and retract shoulder blades — teaches scapular control

exercises.name: Empty Bar Bench Press
exercises.notes: Practice setup: feet placement, arch, shoulder blade retraction, grip width, bar path

exercises.name: Pause Bench Press (Bar Only)
exercises.notes: Practice maintaining tension with bar on chest — critical for heavy lifts

exercises.name: Build-Up Sets (Gradual Load Increase)

intensity.description: Bar → 95 → 135 → 185 → 225 → working weight

exercises.notes: Example for 300lb 1RM (247.5lb ≈ 250lb working weight): Bar×10, 95×5, 135×3, 185×2, 225×1, then 250×3. Each warm-up set deliberate — build confidence.

exercises.name: Competition Bench Press

intensity.description: 82.5% 1RM — Wave Loading Week 2. Third rep challenging but controlled. If stalls mid-press, reduce 5lbs next set.

exercises.tempo: 2 sec descent, 0.5 sec pause, explosive press
exercises.notes: Setup (CRITICAL at 82.5%): Feet planted firmly (drive through floor during press), arch established (upper back arched, not lower back—shoulder blades retracted and locked), grip secure (chalk if needed, thumbs around bar for safety), spotter present and attentive. Execution: Unrack with spotter assist (save energy), position bar over sternum, big breath and brace, lower to chest with control (2sec descent, bar path slightly diagonal toward face), touch lightly (don't bounce), pause 0.5sec (maintain tension, feel bar on chest but don't relax), press explosively (drive through floor with feet, press bar up and slightly toward rack). Breathe at top. Focus: Maintain arch and shoulder blade position throughout set, bar touches same spot every rep (lower sternum), bar path diagonal (not straight up), lockout fully. Bar speed check: first rep should move well, second rep slows, third rep is challenging but should complete without mid-press stall. If bar stalls or takes >3sec, reduce 5lbs next set. Rest 3-4min (sit up, sip water, shake out arms, mentally prepare). Record: weight, reps, RPE, bar speed per rep, bar path quality, any form breakdown (arch collapse? bar path drift?).

sections.title: Secondary Variation
sections.overview: Close-grip bench — reduced volume from accumulation

exercises.name: Close-Grip Bench Press

intensity.description: 65% 1RM — lockout/triceps work, reduced from 4x6 in accumulation

exercises.notes: Setup: Same as competition bench but grip narrower—hands shoulder-width or slightly narrower (not too narrow—elbow stress). Execution: Lower to chest (same touch point), keep elbows tucked closer to body (emphasizes triceps), press explosively. Purpose: Lockout strength, triceps hypertrophy. Volume reduced to preserve energy for main lift.

sections.title: Accessories
sections.overview: Minimal accessories — focus on upper back and shoulder health

exercises.name: Barbell Row (Pendlay or Bent-Over)

intensity.description: Upper back strength — reduced from 4x8 in accumulation

exercises.notes: Execution: Pull bar to sternum, squeeze shoulder blades together, control descent, no momentum. Purpose: Upper back strength for bench stability, shoulder health. Volume reduced but still critical—pull volume prevents shoulder issues.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Incline Press

intensity.description: Upper chest/front delt — moderate hypertrophy work

exercises.notes: Setup: Incline bench 30-45°. Execution: Press dumbbells up and slightly together, control descent (feel stretch in upper chest), full ROM. Purpose: Upper chest hypertrophy, unilateral work.

exercises.name: Face Pulls

intensity.description: Rear delt/shoulder health — ALWAYS do these, even during strength phase

exercises.notes: Setup: Rope attachment on cable, chest height. Execution: Pull rope toward face, externally rotate at end (thumbs point back), squeeze rear delts, control return. Purpose: Shoulder health is non-negotiable. Keep face pulls despite reduced accessories.

exercises.name: Chest Stretch (Doorway)
exercises.notes: Arm on doorframe, lean forward, feel stretch in chest and front shoulder

exercises.name: Shoulder Stretch (Cross-Body)
exercises.notes: Pull arm across body, feel stretch in rear shoulder

exercises.name: Triceps Stretch (Overhead)
exercises.notes: Reach arm overhead, bend elbow, pull elbow with other hand

exercises.name: Band External Rotations

intensity.description: Shoulder health maintenance

exercises.notes: Elbow at side, 90° bend, rotate hand away from body using light band — rotator cuff health

metadata.title: Advanced Week 6 — Thursday (Day 4)
keyFeatures: Deadlifts more fatiguing — may be 2 reps instead of 3
Secondary squat: Front squat 3x5 (lighter than Monday)
Minimal accessories — preserve energy for main lift

structuredWorkout.title: Lower: Deadlift Emphasis
structuredWorkout.description: Week 2 of wave loading: 82.5% 1RM for 4x2-3 @ RPE 8-9. Deadlifts are more fatiguing than squats/bench—some lifters only manage 2 clean reps at this intensity (that's fine). Perfect setup every rep. If second or third rep grinds significantly (>4-5sec) or form breaks down (back rounds), stop set and reduce 10lbs next set. Secondary squat work lighter than Monday. Competition > percentages.

sections.title: Warm-Up
sections.overview: Thorough preparation for 82.5% deadlifts — most demanding main lift

exercises.name: Light Cardio

intensity.description: Walk, bike, or row — warm posterior chain

exercises.notes: Gradually elevate heart rate, warm posterior chain

exercises.name: Leg Swings
exercises.notes: Forward/back and side-to-side — loosen hips and hamstrings

exercises.name: Hip Openers (90/90 Stretch)
exercises.notes: Sit with both legs at 90°, lean forward over front leg — opens hip capsule

exercises.name: Cat-Cow
exercises.notes: Hands and knees, arch and round spine slowly — mobilizes spine for deadlift setup

exercises.name: Empty Bar RDLs
exercises.notes: Practice hip hinge pattern — push hips back, neutral spine, hamstring stretch

exercises.name: Build-Up Sets (Gradual Load Increase)
exercises.notes: Example for 500lb 1RM (412.5lb ≈ 415lb working weight): 135×5, 185×3, 225×2, 275×1, 315×1, 365×1, then 415×2-3. Each warm-up set: perfect setup, focus on bracing and lat engagement.

exercises.name: Competition Deadlift (Conventional or Sumo)

intensity.description: 82.5% 1RM — Wave Loading Week 2. Deadlifts more fatiguing: some lifters only manage 2 clean reps (acceptable). If rep grinds >4-5sec or form breaks, stop set.

exercises.tempo: Perfect setup, explosive pull, controlled descent
exercises.notes: Setup (MOST CRITICAL PART): Feet hip-width (conventional) or wide (sumo), bar over mid-foot (look down—bar should bisect foot), shins vertical, grip just outside legs (mixed or hook grip at this weight—try without straps first), chest up (not down), lats engaged (imagine 'bending bar' around shins—pull slack out, feel tension before pulling), big breath and brace (360° brace—belly, sides, lower back). Execution: Push floor away with legs (don't yank with back), bar scrapes shins/thighs (stays in contact entire lift—if drifts forward, lose leverage), hips and shoulders rise together (don't shoot hips up first—strains back), lockout with glutes (stand tall, squeeze glutes, don't lean back excessively or hitch). Lower with control (controlled descent prevents injury). Focus: Perfect setup EVERY rep, bar speed (if second or third rep is significant grind—takes >4-5sec, form breaks down, back rounds—stop set and reduce 10lbs next set). Reps: Some lifters can do 3 clean reps, others only 2—listen to your body. If first rep is RPE 9.5, do NOT attempt second rep (injury risk). Rest 3-4min (sit down, release belt if wearing, sip water, mentally reset—deadlifts are as mental as physical at 82.5%). Record: weight, reps completed (2 or 3?), RPE per set, bar speed per rep, any form breakdown (back rounding? hips shot up? hitching? bar drifted forward?), grip (did grip hold or slip?).

sections.title: Secondary Variation
sections.overview: Deficit deadlift — reduced volume from accumulation

exercises.name: Deficit Deadlift (1-2 inch platform)

intensity.description: 60-65% 1RM — off-the-floor strength, reduced from 4x3 in accumulation

exercises.notes: Setup: Stand on 1-2 inch platform. Same setup as competition deadlift but starting position lower (bar starts lower, more knee bend required). Execution: Push floor away, bar stays close, hips/shoulders rise together. Purpose: Off-the-floor strength, increased ROM. Volume significantly reduced from accumulation to preserve energy.

sections.title: Secondary Lift
sections.overview: Front squat — secondary squat work (lighter than Monday)

exercises.name: Front Squat OR High-Bar Squat

intensity.description: 60% of back squat 1RM — lighter than Monday's competition squat

exercises.notes: Purpose: Maintains squat frequency (2x per week for skill retention), lighter than Monday's 82.5% competition squat. Front squat: Bar on front delts (elbows high, chest up), teaches upright torso. High-bar: Variation from Monday's low-bar. Focus: Speed and quality, not load.

sections.title: Accessories
sections.overview: Minimal posterior chain work — preserve recovery

exercises.name: Glute-Ham Raise

intensity.description: Posterior chain hypertrophy — reduced volume from accumulation

exercises.notes: Execution: Control eccentric (slow descent), use hands to assist concentric if needed. Purpose: Hamstring/glute hypertrophy, eccentric strength (injury prevention). Volume reduced to preserve recovery.

sections.title: Cooldown
sections.overview: Gentle stretching and lower back care after heavy deadlifts

exercises.name: Hamstring Stretch
exercises.notes: Seated or standing, reach for toes, feel stretch in back of thigh

exercises.name: Glute Stretch (Figure-4)
exercises.notes: Lie on back, cross ankle over opposite knee, pull knee toward chest

exercises.name: Child's Pose
exercises.notes: Kneel, sit back on heels, extend arms forward — gentle lower back stretch after heavy deadlifts

exercises.name: Cat-Cow
exercises.notes: Gentle spinal mobility after deadlifts — arch and round slowly

exercises.name: Light Walking

intensity.description: Flush blood through legs, reduce stiffness

exercises.notes: Slow pace, just for movement and recovery
